question_text: An 18-year-old female patient with seizures is found dead in bed after taking only one AED. What is the risk of sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP)?

options.A: SUDEP risk is negligible in patients on monotherapy
options.B: SUDEP risk is highest in patients with uncontrolled generalized tonic-clonic seizures
options.C: SUDEP risk is only increased in patients with refractory epilepsy on polytherapy
options.D: SUDEP risk is unrelated to seizure frequency or control

question_text: What is the effect of adding a third antiepileptic drug (AED) on seizure control?
Which of the following treatments is commonly used for Landau-Kleffner syndrome?

options.A: Carbamazepine

question_text: Patient with MTS seizure; EEG showed left temporal discharges. What symptoms does he have?

options.A: Left automatism

question_text: In a scenario of dyscognitive auras (Temporal lobe epilepsy), what imaging is typically used for diagnosis?

options.A: CT scan
patient presents with an aura of fear and seizure localization. Which area of the brain is most likely involved?
known case of epilepsy, a female on lamotrigine, wants to start on OCB. What will you tell her?
patient with a first-time seizure, normal physical examination, and normal EEG, regarding his risk of seizure recurrence?

3-year-old boy presented with developmental delay and seizures consisting of tonic seizures, drop attacks, and other types of seizures. What do you expect to find on his EEG (Lennox-Gastaut syndrome)?
2-year-old baby with developmental delay has tonic-clonic seizures and drop seizures. What would you expect to find on the EEG?
medical patient with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, osteoporosis, and on warfarin, what antiepileptic medication should be given?

question_text: In a case scenario of a 30-year-old female patient with bizarre nocturnal movements, what is the likely localization of the seizure focus?

options.A: Frontal operculum

question_text: What is the most common cause of sudden unexpected death in epilepsy?

options.A: Uncontrolled seizures

question_text: Patient with typical symptoms of Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME), what is a characteristic feature?

options.A: Seizure induced by photic stimulation

45-year-old female patient diagnosed with epilepsy is currently on Lacosamide 200 mg BID and Levetiracetam 1500 mg BID. She presented to the epilepsy outpatient clinic for evaluation. She reported a history of generalized seizure preceded by feelings of fear and palpitations. While in the clinic, she had a seizure episode that started with chewing spells and right hand automatism followed by bilateral generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She doesn’t recall the event. Which of the following is the next step in management?
patient has aphasia and multiple seizure types. What is the diagnosis?
patient exhibits seizure semiology characterized by flexion in one limb with extension of the other limb and head turning to the extended limb. Where is the likely localization?

question_text: In the scenario of an elderly patient with comorbidities including renal stones, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and post-stroke seizures, what is the best AED to prescribe?

options.A: Lamictal

question_text: What is the least medication to interact with oral contraceptive pills (OCP)?

options.A: Keppra
scenario about a child who has an attack of stereotypical hyperkinetic behavior occurring during the night (EEG attached showed frontal discharge). What is the diagnosis?

question_text: Multiple seizure types refractory to AEDs

options.A: Indicates the need for increasing AED doses
options.B: Suggests drug-resistant epilepsy requiring specialist evaluation
options.C: Means seizures will resolve spontaneously over time

question_text: In a case of catamenial seizures, which statement is true?

options.A: Estrogen will decrease the seizure threshold
options.C: Seizure frequency is unrelated to menstrual cycle
options.D: Testosterone has no effect on seizure threshold

options.A: child who has 2 episodes of seizure, all occurring when he was in the train, associated with nausea and vomiting. EEG showed posterior discharges. What is the diagnosis?
child with recurrent staring episodes, myoclonus, and rare generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCs) is being treated. Which of the following anti-seizure medications will worsen his seizures?

question_text: Which EEG finding has the best prognostic value in a 9-year-old boy who has frequent staring spells, especially at school?

options.A: Seizure onset
